What is the visitor policy?
VISITOR POLICY
O’Connor Hospital (OCH) restricts access to its campuses to individuals obtaining or seeking health care, accompanying or visiting patients or staff, or conducting lawful business. The County does not restrict visitors based on race, color, gender, national origin, disability, age, religion, marital status, citizenship, gender identity, gender expression, sexual orientation, or any other legally protected classification. Every patient has the right to receive the visitors they designate, including a spouse, domestic partner, another family member, or a friend, and the right to deny such consent at any time.

GENERAL VISITING GUIDELINES
Visitation may be limited by the care team or hospital administration for failure to comply with the guidelines, in response to public health and other crises, and for any other reason that may present a safety or security risk to patients or others. Visiting may be restricted due to patient’s need for privacy or rest, need for privacy or rest by another individual in the patient’s shared room, if there is a health, safety, or infection risk to patient, visitor, or others, as needed because of a pandemic or infectious disease outbreak, or if there are too many visitors at one time for a patient. Visitors with cough, cold or respiratory symptoms may be restricted from visiting the patient. Visitors are expected to comply with instructions given by the staff about the use of personal protective equipment needed when entering and exiting the patient room. Visitors may not engage in behavior presenting a risk or threat to the patient, hospital staff, or others in the immediate environment, that disrupts the functioning of the patient care unit or treatment area, or that creates a messy or unclean environment. Large family gatherings in patient care areas are not allowed for safety and security reasons. Children under 14 years must pass screening requirements per Infection Prevention protocol before visiting the patient. Visitors may not congregate in corridors or other non-established waiting areas. Smoking is not allowed anywhere on Enterprise Campuses. Visitors for Custody patients must have permission from the Sheriff, Department of Correction, or Probation Department. Visitors must not sit or recline on patient beds. Staff may inquire about visitors’ recent exposures and travel, as indicated by Infection Prevention staff. Visitors who may pose a health or safety risk to patient may not be allowed to visit. Visiting may be limited if there are applicable court orders limiting or restraining contact with patient or others. Staff may limit items that are brought into patient’s room for clinical or security reasons.
Is there a policy for discharge planning?
Yes, there is a policy for discharge planning. This policy establishes the process for patient discharge, including comprehensive discharge instructions, post-discharge care coordination, and follow-up appointments to support continuity of care. The policy also mandates medication reconciliation to ensure patient safety and optimal treatment outcomes. The policy applies to all patients receiving care within the hospital, including inpatient and outpatient settings, and healthcare professionals involved in the discharge planning process. The discharge planning process begins promptly upon admission to identify patients' needs for post-discharge care and support. The attending physician, in collaboration with the interdisciplinary care team, assesses the patient's medical condition, social support, and functional abilities to determine appropriate post-discharge care arrangements. The discharge planning team collaborates with patients, their families, and relevant healthcare providers to facilitate seamless transitions of care. The team also assesses and coordinates any necessary post-discharge services, including home healthcare, rehabilitation, medical equipment, physical therapy, or other support services. The attending physician, in consultation with the interdisciplinary care team, determines the appropriate timing and nature of follow-up appointments for each patient. Medication reconciliation is conducted at admission, during the hospital stay, and at the time of discharge. Compliance with this policy is monitored through regular audits and review of discharge planning documentation. All healthcare professionals involved in the discharge planning process receive adequate education and training on the principles and procedures outlined in this policy. This Discharge Planning Policy is approved by the hospital leadership and is reviewed periodically to ensure its continued relevance, effectiveness, and compliance with regulatory standards.
How many visitors are allowed with a patient at one time?
The number of visitors allowed at a time may be limited depending on the patient's condition and the hospital's capacity. It is the policy of O’Connor Hospital (OCH) to ensure the safety and security of patients, visitors, and staff.<</SYS>>

Visitors may not engage in behavior presenting a risk or threat to the patient, hospital staff, or others in the immediate environment, that disrupts the functioning of the patient care unit or treatment area, or that creates a messy or unclean environment. Large family gatherings in patient care areas are not allowed for safety and security reasons. Children under 14 years must pass screening requirements per Infection Prevention protocol before visiting the patient. Visitors may not congregate in corridors or other non-established waiting areas. Smoking is not allowed anywhere on Enterprise Campuses. Visitors for Custody patients must have permission from the Sheriff, Department of Correction, or Probation Department. Visitors must not sit or recline on patient beds. Staff may inquire about visitors’ recent exposures and travel, as indicated by Infection Prevention staff. Visitors who may pose a health or safety risk to patient may not be allowed to visit. Visiting may be limited if there are applicable court orders limiting or restraining contact with patient or others. Staff may limit items that are brought into patient’s room for clinical or security reasons.
Is there a policy for discharge planning?
Yes, there is a policy for discharge planning. This policy establishes the process for patient discharge, including comprehensive discharge instructions, post-discharge care coordination, and follow-up appointments to support continuity of care. The policy also mandates medication reconciliation to ensure patient safety and optimal treatment outcomes. The policy applies to all patients receiving care within the hospital, including inpatient and outpatient settings, and healthcare professionals involved in the discharge planning process. The discharge planning process begins promptly upon admission to identify patients' needs for post-discharge care and support. The attending physician, in collaboration with the interdisciplinary care team, assesses the patient's medical condition, social support, and functional abilities to determine appropriate post-discharge care arrangements. The discharge planning team collaborates with patients, their families, and relevant healthcare providers to facilitate seamless transitions of care. The team also assesses and coordinates any necessary post-discharge services, including home healthcare, rehabilitation, medical equipment, physical therapy, or other support services. The attending physician, in consultation with the interdisciplinary care team, determines the appropriate timing and nature of follow-up appointments for each patient. Medication reconciliation is conducted at admission, during the hospital stay, and at the time of discharge. Compliance with this policy is monitored through regular audits and review of discharge planning documentation. All healthcare professionals involved in the discharge planning process receive adequate education and training on the principles and procedures outlined in this policy. This Discharge Planning Policy is approved by the hospital leadership and is reviewed periodically to ensure its continued relevance, effectiveness, and compliance with regulatory standards.
